concepts.title: About the Poem and Poet
concepts.content: Emily BrontÃ« was a well-known British author who lived in the nineteenth century. She uses nature to express her thoughts and feelings. This poem presents time (past, present, future) as a dialogue between the poet and a happy child. It shows that the past was pleasant but gone, the present is a time of preparation, and the future is unknown but exciting.

examples.text: Past: a soft autumn evening â€” pleasant but ended
Present: a young bird gathering strength to fly away
Future: a mighty, dazzling sea stretching to infinity
Emily and her sisters Charlotte and Anne were all famous writers

keyPoints: Emily BrontÃ«: 19th century British author
Poem is a dialogue between the poet and a child
Nature images represent time: autumn, bird, sea
Past = pleasant but cannot return to it
Future = unknown but exciting and infinite

concepts.title: Understanding the Poem
concepts.content: The poem uses three nature images: (1) Past = 'An Autumn evening soft and mild with a wind that sighs mournfully' (2) Present = 'A green and flowery spray where a young bird sits gathering its power to mount and fly away' (3) Future = 'A sea beneath a cloudless sun; a mighty, glorious, dazzling sea stretching into infinity.'

examples.text: Past: sad (wind sighs mournfully) but pleasant â€” like a sweet memory
Present: active â€” the bird is 'gathering power', preparing for flight
Future: 'stretching into infinity' â€” limitless possibility
Dialogue form: poet asks, child answers in quotes

keyPoints: Three stanzas = three time periods
Autumn = end of something (past is gone)
Bird gathering strength = preparing for the future (present)
Dazzling sea = vast, exciting, unknown future
Rhyme scheme: thee/free, spray/away, one/sun
concepts.funFact: ğŸ¦ A young bird 'gathering its power to fly' is a perfect image of a student at school â€” preparing for the big wide future!

concepts.title: Reading Aloud â€” Rhythm and Intonation
concepts.content: Poetry should be read aloud with proper rhythm (the beat of the poem) and intonation (the rise and fall of the voice). Questions in the poem are read with rising intonation. Answers are read with a thoughtful, slightly falling intonation. The mood changes â€” mournful for the past, hopeful for the present, excited for the future.

examples.text: Rise in pitch for questions: 'What the past is like to thee?'
Slower, softer for past: 'An Autumn evening soft and mild'
Excited, louder for future: 'A mighty, glorious, dazzling sea!'
Rhythm: regular beat makes poem musical and memorable

keyPoints: Rhythm: regular beat in poetry â€” clap while reading to find it
Intonation: rise for questions, fall for statements
Mood shifts: mournful â†’ hopeful â†’ excited across stanzas
Read dialogue parts as actual conversation
Slow down for emotional lines; speed up for energetic ones
concepts.funFact: ğŸµ Poetry was originally sung, not read â€” that's why it has rhythm and beat, just like your favourite songs!

concepts.title: Simile â€” Comparison Using 'as' or 'like'
concepts.content: A simile is an imaginative comparison of two different things that have something in common. A simile always includes the words 'as' or 'like'. For example: 'as tall as a tree', 'as lovely as a flower', 'runs like the wind'. Similes make descriptions vivid and easy to picture.

examples.text: 'as tall as a tree' â€” person's height compared to a tree
'runs like the wind' â€” speed compared to wind
'as lovely as a flower' â€” beauty compared to a flower
From poem: 'Fly as thick as driving rain' (sights flying past)

keyPoints: Simile: imaginative comparison of two different things
Always uses 'as' or 'like'
Both things share one common quality
Makes writing more vivid and descriptive
Examples: as bright as the sun; cried like a baby
concepts.funFact: âœï¸ Ancient Indian poets used similes extensively â€” in Sanskrit poetry, the technique is called 'Upama' and is considered the queen of literary devices!

concepts.title: Metaphor â€” Direct Comparison Without 'as' or 'like'
concepts.content: A metaphor makes a direct comparison without using 'as' or 'like'. It says something IS another thing. For example: 'He is a gem of a person', 'Time is money', 'Books are our friends', 'The clouds are white sheep'. The poem 'Past, Present, Future' has three metaphors â€” the past IS an autumn evening, the present IS a flowery spray, the future IS a sea.

examples.text: 'He is a gem of a person' â€” person IS a gem (precious)
'Time is money' â€” time IS money (don't waste either)
'Books are our friends' â€” books ARE friends (helpful, loyal)
'The clouds are white sheep' â€” clouds ARE sheep (fluffy, moving)

keyPoints: Metaphor: direct comparison without 'as'/'like'
Says something IS something else
Implies qualities without explaining them
Stronger and more direct than simile
Poem has 3 metaphors: past=autumn evening, present=flowery spray, future=sea
concepts.funFact: ğŸŒ Shakespeare used more metaphors than any other writer â€” he created phrases like 'All the world's a stage' that we still use today!

test.question: In the poem, what is the present hour compared to?
options: A green and flowery spray where a young bird sits
A sea beneath a cloudless sun
test.explanation: 'The present hour? A green and flowery spray where a young bird sits gathering its power to mount and fly away.'

test.question: 'As lovely as a flower' is an example of _____.
test.explanation: A simile compares two things using 'as' or 'like'. 'As lovely as a flower' uses 'as' â€” it is a simile.

test.question: 'Time is money' is an example of _____.
test.explanation: A metaphor says something IS something else without 'as'/'like'. 'Time is money' says time directly IS money.

test.question: How does the poem describe the future?
options: A mighty, glorious, dazzling sea stretching into infinity
A young bird on a spray
test.explanation: 'And what is the future? A sea beneath a cloudless sun; a mighty, glorious, dazzling sea stretching into infinity.'

test.question: The poem is presented as a _____.
options: Dialogue between poet and a child
test.explanation: The poem is in dialogue form â€” the poet asks questions ('Tell me, tell me, smiling child') and the child answers.

test.question: Which of these uses 'like' to make a simile?
test.explanation: 'She sings like a bird' uses 'like' to compare her singing to a bird's â€” it is a simile.

test.question: How many metaphors are there in the poem?
test.explanation: Three metaphors: past IS an autumn evening, present IS a flowery spray where a bird sits, future IS a sea.

test.question: Which century did Emily BrontÃ« live in?
test.explanation: Emily BrontÃ« and her sisters were well-known authors who lived in the nineteenth century (1800s).

test.question: The wind in the autumn evening is described as _____.
test.explanation: 'An Autumn evening soft and mild with a wind that sighs mournfully' â€” the wind sighs mournfully.

test.question: 'The clouds are white sheep' â€” what device is this?
test.explanation: Metaphor â€” says clouds ARE sheep without using 'as' or 'like'. Direct comparison.

keyConcepts: Emily BrontÃ«: 19th century British poet, also wrote Wuthering Heights
Poem structure: dialogue between poet and child about past, present, future
Past = autumn evening (pleasant but gone); Present = bird gathering strength; Future = dazzling sea
Simile: comparison using 'as' or 'like' (e.g., as tall as a tree)
Metaphor: direct comparison without 'as'/'like' (e.g., Books are our friends)
Three metaphors in the poem for past, present and future
commonMisconceptions: All comparisons are similes â€” FALSE, metaphors compare without 'as'/'like'
The poem is sad â€” the future is described as exciting and infinite
Metaphor = exaggeration â€” FALSE, metaphor is a type of comparison
realWorldExamples: Mumbai rains = silver rain (connect to Langston Hughes)
School life now = gathering strength like the bird in present stanza
Exam results = mournful autumn or dazzling sea depending on result!
